question:
Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

Which one of the following could be the schedule of the students' reports?
A) Mon. morning: Helen; Mon. afternoon: Robert Tues. morning: Olivia; Tues. afternoon: Irving Wed. morning: Lenore; Wed. afternoon: Kyle
B) Mon. morning: Irving; Mon. afternoon: Olivia Tues. morning: Helen; Tues. afternoon: Kyle Wed. morning: Nina; Wed. afternoon: Lenore
C) Mon. morning: Lenore; Mon. afternoon: Helen Tues. morning: George; Tues. afternoon: Kyle Wed. morning: Robert; Wed. afternoon: Irving
D) Mon. morning: Nina; Mon. afternoon: Helen Tues. morning: Robert; Tues. afternoon: Irving Wed. morning: Olivia; Wed. afternoon: Lenore
E) Mon. morning: Olivia; Mon. afternoon: Nina Tues. morning: Irving; Tues. afternoon: Helen Wed. morning: Kyle; Wed. afternoon: George
chain_of_thought: However, we need to check if all four options are valid. In option A, we have Olivia on Tuesday morning and Robert on Tuesday afternoon, but this is invalid because Robert cannot give an afternoon report. Therefore, option A is not valid. In option E, we have Nina on Monday afternoon and Helen on Monday morning, but this is invalid because Nina did not give a report on Tuesday, so Helen and Irving must both give reports on Wednesday, but this is not the case. Therefore, option E is not valid. Therefore, only B and C are valid options.
full_output:
<think> There are 6 reports over 3 days, with 2 reports each day. Tuesday is the only day George can give a report. On Monday, we have to choose two students from the remaining 7 students. Since neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report, we must choose one of them for the morning report, and one of the remaining 5 students for the afternoon report. On Wednesday, if Nina gave a report on Tuesday, then Helen and Irving must both give reports on Wednesday. If Nina did not give a report on Tuesday, then we can choose any two students from the remaining 5 students. Testing the options, B has Nina on Wednesday, so Helen and Irving must also be on Wednesday, which is valid. In option C, George is on Tuesday, so it is also valid. We cannot test the other options because they have Olivia or Robert giving an afternoon report on Tuesday, which is invalid. Therefore, only B and C are valid options, but we need to check if there are any other valid options.</think>
<think> We can analyze the other options further. In option A, Olivia is on Tuesday morning, so Robert must be on Monday afternoon, which is valid. However, we need to check if there are any other valid options. In option D, Robert is on Tuesday morning, so Helen must be on Monday afternoon, which is valid. However, we need to check if there are any other valid options. In option E, Nina is on Monday afternoon, so Helen must be on Monday morning, which is valid. However, we need to check if there are any other valid options. Therefore, we have found four valid options: B, C, A, and E.</think>
<think> However, we need to check if all four options are valid. In option A, we have Olivia on Tuesday morning and Robert on Tuesday afternoon, but this is invalid because Robert cannot give an afternoon report. Therefore, option A is not valid. In option E, we have Nina on Monday afternoon and Helen on Monday morning, but this is invalid because Nina did not give a report on Tuesday, so Helen and Irving must both give reports on Wednesday, but this is not the case. Therefore, option E is not valid. Therefore, only B and C are valid options.</think>
<ans>B</ans>
hint_sentence: Also, consider the interaction between the "if Nina, then Helen and Irving the next day" condition and the fact that only one of the remaining days after Tuesday can accommodate all three of them.

question:
Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

If Kyle and Lenore do not give reports, then the morning reports on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday, respectively, could be given by
A) Helen, George, and Nina
B) Irving, Robert, and Helen
C) Nina, Helen, and Olivia
D) Olivia, Robert, and Irving
E) Robert, George, and Helen
chain_of_thought: There are three days and six reports. Tuesday is the only day George can give a report. Nina's report can only be on Tuesday. If Nina gives a report on Tuesday, then Helen and Irving must give reports on Wednesday. The only option that satisfies these conditions is C, which has Nina on Tuesday, and Olivia and Irving on Wednesday. If Nina gives a report on Wednesday, then Helen and Irving must give reports on Tuesday. The only option that satisfies these conditions is E, which has Robert on Monday, George on Tuesday, and Helen on Wednesday. However, option E also satisfies the condition that neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report, and that Kyle and Lenore do not give reports. Therefore option E is also a valid answer.
full_output:
<think> There are three days and six reports. Tuesday is the only day George can give a report. Nina's report can only be on Tuesday. If Nina gives a report on Tuesday, then Helen and Irving must give reports on Wednesday. The only option that satisfies these conditions is C, which has Nina on Tuesday, and Olivia and Irving on Wednesday. If Nina gives a report on Wednesday, then Helen and Irving must give reports on Tuesday. The only option that satisfies these conditions is E, which has Robert on Monday, George on Tuesday, and Helen on Wednesday. However, option E also satisfies the condition that neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report, and that Kyle and Lenore do not give reports. Therefore option E is also a valid answer.</think>
<ans>E</ans>
hint_sentence: Since Nina's report can only be on Tuesday, check the options where Nina's report is on Tuesday and see which one forces Helen and Irving to give reports on the next day.

Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

Which one of the following is a pair of students who, if they give reports on the same day as each other, must give reports on Wednesday?
A) George and Lenore
B) Helen and Nina
C) Irving and Robert
D) Kyle and Nina
E) Olivia and Kyle
chain_of_thought: Let's start by looking at the restrictions on Tuesday. We know that George must give a report on Tuesday, and since there are only two reports on Tuesday, there are only two remaining slots: one in the morning and one in the afternoon. Since Olivia and Robert cannot give an afternoon report, the afternoon report on Tuesday must be given by either Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, or Nina. However, since Nina gives a report on Tuesday, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday. If Nina gives a report on Tuesday, then Helen and Irving must give reports on Wednesday. The only other option for Tuesday is for Nina to give the morning report, which leaves the afternoon report for either Helen or Irving. However, since Helen and Irving must give reports on the next day, it cannot be that Nina gives the morning report on Tuesday. Therefore, if Nina gives a report on Tuesday, it must be the afternoon report. This means that Nina gives a report on Tuesday, and Helen and Irving must give reports on Wednesday. Now let's look at the options: A has George and Lenore, but George only gives a report on Tuesday, so this is not a pair that gives reports on the same day. B has Helen and Nina, but Nina gives a report on Tuesday, so this is not a pair that gives reports on the same day. C has Irving and Robert, but since Robert cannot give an afternoon report, this is not a pair that gives reports on the same day. D has Kyle and Nina, but Nina gives a report on Tuesday, so this is not a pair that gives reports on the same day. E has Olivia and Kyle, but neither of these students is restricted from giving a report on the same day, so this is a pair that could give reports on the same day. However, since we know that Nina gives a report on Tuesday, and Helen and Irving must give reports on the next day, this pair must give reports on Wednesday, and therefore E is the correct answer.

question:
Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

If George, Nina, and Robert give reports and they do so on different days from one another, which one of the following could be true?
A) Helen gives a report on Wednesday.
B) Nina gives a report on Monday.
C) Nina gives a report on Tuesday.
D) Olivia gives a report on Monday.
E) Robert gives a report on Wednesday.
chain_of_thought: The problem has several constraints that need to be analyzed: George can only give a report on Tuesday, Olivia and Robert cannot give afternoon reports, and Nina's report has implications for the next day's reports if given. There are three days: Mon, Tue, Wed. We are told that George, Nina, and Robert give reports on different days, and we are given a set of possible options to consider. Since George must be on Tuesday, we can start by eliminating options that do not place George on Tuesday. Options B and D are eliminated because they place George on Monday. Option E is also eliminated because it places Robert on Wednesday, which would not allow him to give an afternoon report on a different day. The remaining options are A, C, and E is eliminated so we look at A and C. Option C says that Nina gives a report on Tuesday. This would mean that on Wednesday, Helen and Irving must give reports, and Robert must give a report on Monday (because George is on Tuesday and Robert is not on Wednesday). This is a valid combination. Option A says that Helen gives a report on Wednesday. If Helen gives a report on Wednesday, then Nina's report must be on Monday or Tuesday. If Nina gives a report on Monday, then Robert must give a report on Tuesday or Wednesday, but Robert cannot give a report on Wednesday because he cannot give an afternoon report on a different day. Therefore, option A is not valid. However, option C is valid, so the correct answer is option C.
full_output:
<think>  The problem has several constraints that need to be analyzed: George can only give a report on Tuesday, Olivia and Robert cannot give afternoon reports, and Nina's report has implications for the next day's reports if given. There are three days: Mon, Tue, Wed. We are told that George, Nina, and Robert give reports on different days, and we are given a set of possible options to consider. Since George must be on Tuesday, we can start by eliminating options that do not place George on Tuesday. Options B and D are eliminated because they place George on Monday. Option E is also eliminated because it places Robert on Wednesday, which would not allow him to give an afternoon report on a different day. The remaining options are A, C, and E is eliminated so we look at A and C. Option C says that Nina gives a report on Tuesday. This would mean that on Wednesday, Helen and Irving must give reports, and Robert must give a report on Monday (because George is on Tuesday and Robert is not on Wednesday). This is a valid combination. Option A says that Helen gives a report on Wednesday. If Helen gives a report on Wednesday, then Nina's report must be on Monday or Tuesday. If Nina gives a report on Monday, then Robert must give a report on Tuesday or Wednesday, but Robert cannot give a report on Wednesday because he cannot give an afternoon report on a different day. Therefore, option A is not valid. However, option C is valid, so the correct answer is option C.</think>
<ans>C</ans>
hint_sentence: Since George's report must be on Tuesday, consider the implications of Nina's report on the following day. If Nina gives a report on Monday, Robert's report would have to be on Tuesday or Wednesday; if Nina gives a report on Tuesday, Robert must give a report on Wednesday, which is not allowed since he can't give an afternoon report on a different day. Use this information to check the validity of each option against the remaining rules.

question:
Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

If Helen, Kyle, and Lenore, not necessarily in that order, give the three morning reports, which one of the following must be true?
A) Helen gives a report on Monday.
B) Irving gives a report on Monday.
C) Irving gives a report on Wednesday.
D) Kyle gives a report on Tuesday.
E) Kyle gives a report on Wednesday.
chain_of_thought: Since there are three days, each with two reports, and Tuesday is the only day that George can give a report, George must give a report on Tuesday. Nina must give a report on Tuesday, because if she gave a report on Monday, then Helen and Irving would have to give reports on Wednesday, which would mean that there is no one left to give the report on Wednesday morning.  If Nina's report is given on Wednesday, then Helen and Irving must give reports on Wednesday, but since Helen and Irving give the morning reports, this is impossible.  Therefore, Nina must give a report on Tuesday.  Now, since Helen, Kyle, and Lenore give the three morning reports, and George and Nina give reports on Tuesday, the only remaining morning report is on Wednesday.  Therefore, Helen, Kyle, and Lenore must give the reports on Monday and Tuesday.  Since Helen gives a report on Monday, option A is true.
full_output:
<think>  Since there are three days, each with two reports, and Tuesday is the only day that George can give a report, George must give a report on Tuesday. Nina must give a report on Tuesday, because if she gave a report on Monday, then Helen and Irving would have to give reports on Wednesday, which would mean that there is no one left to give the report on Wednesday morning.  If Nina's report is given on Wednesday, then Helen and Irving must give reports on Wednesday, but since Helen and Irving give the morning reports, this is impossible.  Therefore, Nina must give a report on Tuesday.  Now, since Helen, Kyle, and Lenore give the three morning reports, and George and Nina give reports on Tuesday, the only remaining morning report is on Wednesday.  Therefore, Helen, Kyle, and Lenore must give the reports on Monday and Tuesday.  Since Helen gives a report on Monday, option A is true.</think>
<ans>A</ans>
hint_sentence: Since Nina's report is on Tuesday, and Helen and Irving must give reports on Wednesday if Nina's report is not on Wednesday, consider what happens if Helen and Irving give their reports on Wednesday. In this case, the only morning report left for Wednesday is already taken by either Kyle or Lenore, so check which of the options could be true if Helen and Irving are not on Monday.

question:
The organizer of a reading club will select at least five and at most six works from a group of nine works. The group consists of three French novels, three Russian novels, two French plays, and one Russian play. The organizer's selection of works must conform to the following requirements: No more than four French works are selected. At least three but no more than four novels are selected. At least as many French novels as Russian novels are selected. If both French plays are selected, then the Russian play is not selected.

Which one of the following could be the organizer's selection of works?
A) one French novel, two Russian novels, one French play, one Russian play
B) two French novels, one Russian novel, two French plays, one Russian play
C) two French novels, two Russian novels, two French plays
D) three French novels, one Russian novel, two French plays
E) three French novels, two Russian novels, one Russian play
chain_of_thought: Let's break down the constraints: at most 4 French works, at least 3 but no more than 4 novels, at least as many French novels as Russian novels, and if both French plays are selected, then the Russian play is not selected. We need to find a combination that satisfies all these constraints. Option A has 1 French novel and 2 Russian novels, which satisfies the novel count constraint. It also has 1 French play and 1 Russian play, satisfying the play count constraint. Since there is only 1 French play, the Russian play can be included, so A satisfies all constraints. We need to test the other options to see if they also satisfy the constraints. Option B has 2 French novels and 2 French plays, which means the Russian play cannot be included. Option C has 2 French novels, 2 Russian novels, and 2 French plays, which means the Russian play cannot be included. Option D has 3 French novels, 1 Russian novel, and 2 French plays, which means the Russian play cannot be included. Option E has 3 French novels and 1 Russian play, which satisfies the novel count constraint. However, it does not satisfy the constraint that at least as many French novels as Russian novels are selected. Therefore, only option A satisfies all constraints.
full_output:
<think> Let's break down the constraints: at most 4 French works, at least 3 but no more than 4 novels, at least as many French novels as Russian novels, and if both French plays are selected, then the Russian play is not selected. We need to find a combination that satisfies all these constraints. Option A has 1 French novel and 2 Russian novels, which satisfies the novel count constraint. It also has 1 French play and 1 Russian play, satisfying the play count constraint. Since there is only 1 French play, the Russian play can be included, so A satisfies all constraints. We need to test the other options to see if they also satisfy the constraints. Option B has 2 French novels and 2 French plays, which means the Russian play cannot be included. Option C has 2 French novels, 2 Russian novels, and 2 French plays, which means the Russian play cannot be included. Option D has 3 French novels, 1 Russian novel, and 2 French plays, which means the Russian play cannot be included. Option E has 3 French novels and 1 Russian play, which satisfies the novel count constraint. However, it does not satisfy the constraint that at least as many French novels as Russian novels are selected. Therefore, only option A satisfies all constraints.</think>
<ans>A</ans>
hint_sentence: Since at least as many French novels as Russian novels must be selected, consider the possible combinations of French and Russian novels separately before combining them with the plays.

question:

The organizer's selection of works must conform to the following requirements: No more than four French works are selected. At least three but no more than four novels are selected. Which one of the following could be true about the organizer's selection of works?
A) No Russian novels are selected.
B) Exactly one French novel is selected.
C) All three plays are selected.
D) All three Russian novels are selected.
E) All five French works are selected.
chain_of_thought: Let's break down the requirements. The organizer selects at least five and at most six works. B) If exactly one French novel is selected, then there must be two or three Russian novels selected, so there are at least as many Russian novels as French novels selected. However, there can be at most two French works selected, so this violates the requirement that no more than four French works are selected. C) If all three plays are selected, then the Russian play is not selected, so this is allowed. There are three plays and three novels selected, so this satisfies the requirements that at least three but no more than four novels are selected and no more than four French works are selected. D) If all three Russian novels are selected, then there can be at most three French novels selected, violating the requirement that at least three but no more than four novels are selected. E) If all five French works are selected, then there are three French novels and two French plays selected, so there are at least as many French novels as Russian novels selected. However, there are only two Russian works selected, so this violates the requirement that at least three but no more than four novels are selected. Therefore, only option C could be true about the organizer's selection of works.

No more than four French works are selected. This means that there can be 0, 1, 2, 3, or 4 French works selected, but not 5 or 6. At least three but no more than four novels are selected. This means that there can be 3 or 4 novels selected. At least as many French novels as Russian novels are selected. If both French plays are selected, then the Russian play is not selected. We need to test each option against these requirements. A) If no Russian novels are selected, then there are three Russian novels not selected, so there can be at most three French novels selected, violating the requirement that at least three but no more than four novels are selected. D) If all three Russian novels are selected, then there can be at most three French novels selected, violating the requirement that at least three but no more than four novels are selected. E) If all five French works are selected, then there are three French novels and two French plays selected, so there are at least as many French novels as Russian novels selected. However, there are only two Russian works selected, so this violates the requirement that at least three but no more than four novels are selected. Therefore, only option C could be true about the organizer's selection of works.</think>
<ans>C</ans>

This rule will help to narrow down the possibilities for the number of French and Russian novels in the selection, and from there, you can test each option against the other requirements.

question:
The organizer of a reading club will select at least five and at most six works from a group of nine works. The group consists of three French novels, three Russian novels, two French plays, and one Russian play. The organizer's selection of works must conform to the following requirements: No more than four French works are selected. At least three but no more than four novels are selected. At least as many French novels as Russian novels are selected. If both French plays are selected, then the Russian play is not selected.

If the works selected include three French novels, which one of the following could be a complete and accurate list of the remaining works selected?
A) one Russian novel
B) two French plays
C) one Russian novel, one Russian play
D) one Russian novel, two French plays
E) two Russian novels, one French play
chain_of_thought: We know there are three French novels, and since at least three but no more than four novels are selected, there must be at least three Russian novels. There are only three Russian novels, so exactly three Russian novels must be selected. Since at least as many French novels as Russian novels are selected, and there are three French novels, we must select all three French novels. This leaves us with three remaining works to select. We have two French plays and one Russian play, and we can select at most four French works, so we can select at most one French play. If both French plays are selected, then the Russian play is not selected, so we can select at most one French play. Therefore, we can select either one French play and two Russian works, or no French plays and three Russian works. Since we have already selected three French novels, we must select one French play and two Russian works. Option D has one Russian novel, one Russian play, and two French works, which is a total of five works. Since we have already selected three French novels, we need to select two more works, which is exactly what option D provides.

Since at least as many French novels as Russian novels are selected, and there are three French novels, we must select all three French novels. This leaves us with three remaining works to select. We have two French plays and one Russian play, and we can select at most four French works, so we can select at most one French play. If both French plays are selected, then the Russian play is not selected, so we can select at most one French play. Therefore, we can select either one French play and two Russian works, or no French plays and three Russian works. Since we have already selected three French novels, we must select one French play and two Russian works. Option D has one Russian novel, one Russian play, and two French works, which is a total of five works.
